bullets.content: Use pathlib.Path over os.path for file operations
Use httpx async client over requests for HTTP calls
MCP tools must return JSON-serializable dicts wrapped in result key
Always pass project path explicitly - never assume cwd
When implementing cross-platform features, verify hook support via web search first - Cursor has hooks (v1.7+), Windsurf has enterprise-only Cascade Hooks, VS Code Copilot and Gemini have no hooks

DELIA METHODOLOGY CAPTURE: Before completing a task, ask 'What did I do differently that worked?' and add that methodology as a playbook bullet. This closes the Delia learning loop and teaches future models.

Delia enforcement should go beyond tool call gating - it should also enforce structured responses that capture HOW problems were solved, not just WHAT was found. This enables cross-model learning where Opus's debugging methodology becomes available to Haiku/Sonnet via playbook bullets.

When analyzing tool gaps, always read actual implementation files rather than relying on exploration summaries - several items flagged as missing were already implemented (ToolResult standardization, success reflection)

When adding new MCP tools, follow the pattern: implement core function in domain file (coding.py, files.py), then create thin @mcp.tool() wrapper in handlers.py or resources.py that handles JSON parsing and calls the implementation.
For MCP tool categorization, pattern-based matching on tool names is more pragmatic than updating every tool registration - existing tools work immediately without code changes.
For per-project isolation of singletons, use a Manager pattern with dict[project_path, Instance] protected by threading.Lock. Normalize paths with Path.resolve() for consistent keys.
Hard gating removes LLM discretion - when tools return blocking errors, the LLM has no choice but to comply. This is more effective than soft warnings which LLMs can ignore.
Delia's edit_file tool does not support replace_all parameter - use Claude Code's Edit tool with replace_all:true for bulk replacements

When adding quality validation to a function, make strictness configurable based on source (manual vs automated) and distinguish between hard errors (blocking) and soft warnings (logged but not blocking) to allow flexibility without compromising safety
When debugging FastMCP API issues, use `dir(mcp)` to discover actual methods - FastMCP uses get_tools() (async, returns dict) not list_tools()
